statements.name: PROC CORRESP
statements.description: The CORRESP procedure performs simple correspondence analysis and multiple correspondence analysis (MCA). You can use correspondence analysis to find a low-dimensional graphical representation of the rows and columns of a crosstabulation or contingency table. Each row and column is represented by a point in a plot determined from the cell frequencies. PROC CORRESP can also compute coordinates for supplementary rows and columns. † PROC CORRESP can read two kinds of input: raw categorical responses on two or more classification variables or a two-way contingency table. The correspondence analysis plot is displayed with ODS Graphics.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Is equivalent to specifying the OBSERVED, RP, CP, CELLCHI2, EXPECTED, and DEVIATION options.

arguments.name: BENZECRI
arguments.description: Displays adjusted inertias when performing multiple correspondence analysis.

arguments.name: BINARY
arguments.description: Enables you to create binary tables easily. When you specify the BINARY option, specify only column variables in the TABLES statement. Each input data set observation forms a single row in the constructed table.

arguments.name: CELLCHI2
arguments.description: Displays the contribution to the total chi-square test statistic for each cell.

arguments.name: COLUMN=
arguments.description: Provides other standardizations of the column coordinates. The COLUMN= option is rarely needed. Typically, you should use the PROFILE= option instead.
arguments.help: COLUMN=B | BD | DB | DBD | DBD1/2 | DBID1/2

arguments.name: B
arguments.description: Matrix formula B

arguments.name: BD
arguments.description: Matrix formula BDu

arguments.name: DB
arguments.description: Matrix formula Dc⁻¹B

arguments.name: DBD
arguments.description: Matrix formula Dc⁻¹BDu

arguments.name: DBD1/2
arguments.description: Matrix formula Dc⁻¹BDu^1/2

arguments.name: DBID1/2
arguments.description: Matrix formula Dc⁻¹B(I+Du)^1/2

arguments.name: CP
arguments.description: Displays the column profile matrix. Column profiles contain the observed conditional probabilities of row membership given column membership.

arguments.name: CROSS=
arguments.description: Specifies the method of crossing (factorially combining) the levels of the TABLES variables.

arguments.name: COLUMN
arguments.description: Causes each combination of levels for all column variables to become a column label, whereas each level of every row variable becomes a row label.

arguments.name: ROW
arguments.description: Causes each combination of levels for all row variables to become a row label, whereas each level of every column variable becomes a column label.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Causes each combination of levels for all row variables to become a row label and each combination of levels for all column variables to become a column label.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Causes each level of every row variable to become a row label and each level of every column variable to become a column label.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the SAS data set to be used by PROC CORRESP.

arguments.name: DEVIATION
arguments.description: Displays the matrix of deviations between the observed frequency matrix and the product of its row marginals and column marginals divided by its grand frequency.

arguments.name: DIMENS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of dimensions or axes to use. The default is DIMENS=2.

arguments.name: EXPECTED
arguments.description: Displays the product of the row marginals and the column marginals divided by the grand frequency of the observed frequency table.

arguments.name: FREQOUT
arguments.description: Indicates that the PROC CORRESP input data set has the same form as an output data set from the FREQ procedure, even if it was not directly produced by PROC FREQ. The FREQOUT option enables PROC CORRESP to take shortcuts in constructing the contingency table.

arguments.name: GREENACRE
arguments.description: Displays adjusted inertias when you are performing multiple correspondence analysis.

arguments.name: MCA
arguments.description: Requests a multiple correspondence analysis.

arguments.name: MININERTIA=
arguments.description: Specifies the minimum inertia (0 ≤ n ≤ 1) used to create the "best" tables—the indicator of which points best explain the inertia of each dimension.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Specifies that observations with missing values for the TABLES statement variables are included in the analysis. Missing values are treated as a distinct level of each categorical variable.

arguments.name: NOCOLUMN=
arguments.description: Suppresses the display of the column coordinates and statistics and omits them from the output coordinate data set.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: Suppresses all column information from the output data set.

arguments.name: PRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses all column information from the SAS listing.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Suppresses all column information from both the SAS listing and the output data set.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the display of all output.

arguments.name: NOROW=
arguments.description: Suppresses the display of the row coordinates and statistics and omits them from the output coordinate data set.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: Suppresses all row information from the output data set.

arguments.name: PRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses all row information from the SAS listing.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Suppresses all row information from both the SAS listing and the output data set.

arguments.name: NVARS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of classification variables that were used to create the Burt table.

arguments.name: OBSERVED
arguments.description: Displays the contingency table of observed frequencies and its row, column, and grand totals.

arguments.name: OUTC=
arguments.description: Creates an output coordinate SAS data set to contain the row, column, supplementary observation, and supplementary variable coordinates.

arguments.name: OUTF=
arguments.description: Creates an output frequency SAS data set to contain the contingency table, row, and column profiles, the expected values, and the observed minus expected values and contributions to the chi-square statistic.

arguments.name: PLOTS=
arguments.description: Specifies options that control the details of the plots. Syntax: (1) PLOTS<(global-plot-options)> <= plot-request <(options)>> (2) PLOTS<(global-plot-options)> <= (plot-request <(options)> <... plot-request <(options)>>)> The global plot option is as follows: FLIP FLI flips or interchanges the X-axis and Y-axis dimensions. The plot requests include the following: ALL produces all appropriate plots.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Produces all appropriate plots.

arguments.name: CONFIGURATION
arguments.description: Produces the configuration plot.

arguments.name: INERTIA
arguments.description: Produces an inertia decomposition chart and specifies inertia-options.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses all plots.

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Affects the OBSERVED, RP, CP, CELLCHI2, EXPECTED, and DEVIATION options. The default is PRINT=FREQ.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Displays both percentages and frequencies.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: Displays output in the appropriate raw or natural units.

arguments.name: PERCENT
arguments.description: Scales results to percentages for the display of the output.

arguments.name: PROFILE=
arguments.description: [plot request] Specifies the method of crossing (factorially combining) the levels of the TABLES variables.

arguments.name: COLUMN
arguments.description: Specifies a correspondence analysis of the column profile matrix. The column coordinates are weighted centroids of the row coordinates.

arguments.name: ROW
arguments.description: Specifies a correspondence analysis of the row profile matrix. The row coordinates are weighted centroids of the column coordinates.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Specifies a standard correspondence analysis, which jointly displays the principal row and column coordinates.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Is rarely needed. Row and column coordinates are the generalized singular vectors, without the customary standardizations.

arguments.name: ROW=
arguments.description: [plot request] Provides other standardizations of the row coordinates.
arguments.help: ROW=A | AD | DA | DAD | DAD1/2 | DAID1/2

arguments.name: A
arguments.description: Matrix formula A

arguments.name: AD
arguments.description: Matrix formula ADu

arguments.name: DA
arguments.description: Matrix formula (Dc)⁻¹1A

arguments.name: DAD
arguments.description: Matrix formula (Dc)⁻¹1ADu

arguments.name: DAD1/2
arguments.description: Matrix formula (Dc)⁻¹ADu^1/2

arguments.name: DAID1/2
arguments.description: Matrix formula (Dc)⁻¹A(I+Du)^1/2

arguments.name: RP
arguments.description: Displays the row profile matrix. Row profiles contain the observed conditional probabilities of column membership given row membership.

arguments.name: SHORT
arguments.description: Suppresses the display of all point and coordinate statistics except the coordinates.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Specifies the largest value that is considered to be within rounding error of zero.

arguments.name: SOURCE
arguments.description: Adds the variable _VAR_, which contains the name or label of the variable corresponding to the current level, to the OUTC= and OUTF= data sets.

arguments.name: UNADJUSTED
arguments.description: Displays unadjusted inertias when performing multiple correspondence analysis.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Obtains separate analyses on observations in groups defined by the BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: You specify the ID statement only in conjunction with the VAR statement. You cannot specify the ID statement when you use the TABLES statement or the MCA option. When you specify an ID variable, PROC CORRESP labels the rows of the tables with the ID values and places the ID variable in the output data set.

statements.name: SUPPLEMENTARY
statements.description: The SUPPLEMENTARY statement specifies variables that are to be represented as points in the joint row and column space but that are not used in determining the locations of the other, active row and column points of the contingency table.

statements.name: TABLES
statements.description: The TABLES statement instructs PROC CORRESP to create a contingency table, Burt table, or binary table from the values of two or more categorical variables.

statements.name: VAR
statements.description: You should specify the VAR statement when your data are in tabular form. The VAR variables must be numeric. The VAR statement instructs PROC CORRESP to read an existing contingency table, binary indicator matrix, fuzzy-coded indicator matrix, or Burt table, rather than raw data.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: The WEIGHT statement specifies weights for each observation and indicates supplementary observations for simple correspondence analyses with VAR statement input. You can include only one WEIGHT statement, and the weight variable must be numeric.
